CHAPTER IV.—That property sure to be taken is not held as taken aad required by the enemy.

Cephalus holds that “a thing is called captured when it can not escape capture,” and he applies this dictum to a certain case ol pirates. Molina applies it to wild beasts which have been injured by one hunter and ultimately taken by another. But “to pirates and wild beasts no territory offers safety.’' Now this principle is not true in war, of our Spaniards, lor instance, who are safe in neutral territory. If a wild boar falls into a snare which 1 have set and you let him go free, he ceases to be mine. The boar might have been able to lree himself.
